messages.subject: Re: Nobuie Tsuba Terminology
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Milt!  Hope all is well with you and your family.  I have to wonder if sometimes what we think is fire scale may actually be oil rust which is lifting the
messages.messageBody:
Hi Milt! Hope all is well with you and your family. I have to
wonder if sometimes what we think is 'fire scale' may actually be oil
rust which is lifting the oxidized outer layer of the metal? Also I
have to wonder if the effect might be explainable to analogize to
the 'glazing' process of dental porcalain (I just had to get
dentistry into this to bug you) which is when you subject the object
to very high heat for short duration which only melts the surface as
opposed to lower heat of longer duration (as in a fire) which more
evenly heats the object. Something for the metalurgists to ponder.---
In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "bungotakadasword"
<MuramasaIII@a...> wrote:
> " yakite shitate = a surface finish resembling the glaze on
pottery.
> Produced by
> putting the finished plate back into the furnace and allowing the
> surface to
> melt slightly. "
>
>
> this brings to mind about the effect of " fire damage " we
sometimes
> see in tsuba................
> How come some tsuba develop " fire scales " and some develop " a
> surface finish resembling the glaze on pottery " ?
> I used to have a tsuba with gold nunome AND " fire scales "......if
> that tsuba was under fire high enough to develop fire scales, then
how
> come the gold nunome did not melt ?
> Assuming fire scales develop under " low heat ", then can we repair
the
> fire damage by subjecting the tsuba to high heat , at least we'll
get
> a Hoan look ?
>
> milt

messages.subject: Re: Nobuie Tsuba Terminology
messages.msgSnippet: yakite shitate = a surface finish resembling the glaze on pottery. Produced by putting the finished plate back into the furnace and allowing the surface to
messages.messageBody:
" yakite shitate = a surface finish resembling the glaze on pottery.
Produced by
putting the finished plate back into the furnace and allowing the
surface to
melt slightly. "


this brings to mind about the effect of " fire damage " we sometimes
see in tsuba................
How come some tsuba develop " fire scales " and some develop " a
surface finish resembling the glaze on pottery " ?
I used to have a tsuba with gold nunome AND " fire scales "......if
that tsuba was under fire high enough to develop fire scales, then how
come the gold nunome did not melt ?
Assuming fire scales develop under " low heat ", then can we repair the
fire damage by subjecting the tsuba to high heat , at least we'll get
a Hoan look ?

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nobuie Tsuba Terminology
messages.msgSnippet: tetsu-ji = surface of the iron plate yakite shitate = a surface finish resembling the glaze on pottery.  Produced by putting the finished plate back into the
messages.messageBody:
tetsu-ji = surface of the iron plate

yakite shitate = a surface finish resembling the glaze on pottery. Produced by putting the finished plate back into the furnace and allowing the surface to melt slightly.

ji-mon = a pattern of hammer marks on the surface of the tsuba.

tetkotsu = "bones." Lumps produced as the result of the steel being made of a mixture of irons of differing hardness. A key feature in the eyes of tsuba aficionadoes.

mimi = the edge.



What you want to do is get hold of a copy of:

Alan L. Harvie (editor), Tsuba - An Aesthetic Study by Kazutaro Torigoye and Robert E. Hayes, translated from the Tsuba Geijutsu-K么 of Kazutaro Torigoye, Northern California Japanese Sword Club, N.P., March, 2000.



in which you will find a handy glossary, as well as a course in tsuba fundamentals. It is available via:



http://www.ncjsc.org/











----- Original Message -----
From: klepet33319
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, April 30, 2005 7:18 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Nobuie Tsuba Terminology


Good evening and I hope all are having a great weekend. Would someone
please explain the following:
'The tetsu-ji of Nobuiye tsuba is strong and sometimes famous yakite
shitate and jimon appears with prominent tetkotsu in mimi'.
It is taken from the collection notes of Mr. James Meyer. Thanks much!

messages.messageBody:
Good evening and I hope all are having a great weekend. Would someone
please explain the following:
'The tetsu-ji of Nobuiye tsuba is strong and sometimes famous yakite
shitate and jimon appears with prominent tetkotsu in mimi'.
It is taken from the collection notes of Mr. James Meyer. Thanks much!
